facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 577 of 1963 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 577 of 1963. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal arose from judgment and order dated March 8, 1961 of Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 1120 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated March 8, 1961 of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 1120- of 1960.

facts.text: Appellant took on lease two survey numbers from respondent Sholapur Borough Municipality on April 1, 1946 for three years.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant took on lease two survey numbers from the respondent, Sholapur Borough Municipality on April 1, 1946 for a period of three years.

facts.text: Leased land is situated within municipal limits.

anchor.surface_text: The land is situate within the municipal limits.

facts.text: Bombay Tenancy Act No. 29 of 1939 was applied to this area about November 8, 1946 via Bombay Tenancy Amendment Act No. XXVI of 1946.

anchor.surface_text: About November 8, 1946, the Bombay Tenancy Act, No. 29 of 1939  hereinafter referred to as the 1939-Act  was applied to this area and s. 3-A of that Act

facts.text: Section 3-A of 1939 Act deemed every tenant a protected tenant unless landlord applied to Mamlatdar within one year.

anchor.surface_text: provided that every tenant shall on the expiry of one year from the date of the companying into force of the Bombay Tenancy  Amendment  Act,  No. XXVI of 1946  be deemed to be a protected tenant

facts.text: Respondent did not file application within one year, so appellant claimed protected tenant status under 1939 Act.

anchor.surface_text: unless his landlord has within the said period made an application to the Mamlatdar for a declaration that the tenant was number a protected one. The respondent did number file a suit within one year

facts.text: 1939 Act was repealed in 1948 by Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act No. LXVII of 1948.

anchor.surface_text: and therefore the appellant claimed to have become a protected tenant under the 1939-Act. The 1939-Act was repeated in 1948 by the Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, No. LXVII of 1948

facts.text: Section 31 of 1948 Act recognized protected tenants deemed under ss. 3, 3-A, 4 of 1939 Act.

anchor.surface_text: hereinafter referred to as the 1948-Act . Section 31 of the 1948-Act provided that for the purposes of this Act, a person shall be recognised to be a protected tenant if such person had been deemed to be a protected tenant under s. 3, 3-A or 4 of the 1939-Act.

facts.text: Section 88 of 1948 Act provided nothing in foregoing provisions applies to lands held on lease from local authority.

anchor.surface_text: Ordinarily, therefore, the appellant would have become a protected tenant under this section of the 1948-Act, if he had become a protected tenant under the 1939Act. But s. 88 of the 1948-Act inter alia provided that numberhing in the foregoing provisions of the 1948-Act shall apply to lands held on lease from a local authority.

facts.text: Respondent gave notice to appellant on May 2, 1955 terminating tenancy effective March 31, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the respondent gave numberice to the appel- lant on May 2, 1955 terminating his tenancy with effect from March 31, 1956.

facts.text: Respondent filed Suit No. 42 of 1957 for possession and other reliefs.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently the respondent filed suit No. 42 of 1957 for obtaining possession of the lands and for certain other reliefs.

facts.text: Trial court in Suit 42/1957 held appellant entitled to benefit of 1948 Act and dismissed respondent's suit for possession.

anchor.surface_text: It was held in that suit that the respondent companyld number get possession of the lands as the appellant was entitled to the benefit of the 1948-Act and companysequently the respondents suit for pos session was dismissed.

facts.text: Respondent appealed trial court decision to District Court.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then appealed to the, District Court.

facts.text: Appellant applied on September 8, 1958 for declaration as protected tenant and fixing rent under Tenancy Act during pendency of District Court appeal.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of that appeal the appellant made an application on September 8, 1958 for a declaration that he was a protected tenant of the lands and also for fixig rent under the provisions of the Tenancy Act.

facts.text: Compromise in District Court appeal: set aside dismissal order, remanded suit to trial court with direction to stay and dispose after Mamlatdar decision.

anchor.surface_text: Further in the appeal filed in the District Court a companypromise was arrived at by which the order dismissing the respondents suit for possession was set aside and the suit was remanded to the trial companyrt with the direction that the suit be stayed and disposed of after the decision by the Mamlatdar.

facts.text: Compromise provided: if appellant held tenant under 1948 Act, dismiss possession suit; if against, decree possession.

anchor.surface_text: The companypromise provided that if the appellant was finally held to be tenant by the authorities under the 1948Act the suit for possession would be dismissed. It also provided that if the decision in the proceedings under the, Tenancy Act went against the appellant, the suit for possession would be decreed.

facts.text: Mamlatdar held appellant a tenant and gave declaration under s.70B of 1948 Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Mamlatdar held that the appellant was a tenant and gave him a declaration under s. 70  b  of the 1948-Act.

facts.text: Respondent appealed Mamlatdar decision to Collector, who held no jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then went in appeal to the Collector, and the Collector decided that the Mamlatdar had numberjurisdiction to decide whether the appellant was a tenant.

facts.text: Appellant filed revision to Bombay Revenue Tribunal against Collector order.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then went in revision to the Bombay Revenue Tribunal.

facts.text: Bombay Revenue Tribunal held revenue court had jurisdiction due to 1956 Amendment introducing s.88B, remanded to Collector on merits.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal held, in view of the amendments that had been made in the 1948-Act by the Amendment Act of 1956 by which s. 88- B was introduced in the 1948-Act, that the revenue companyrt had jurisdiction to decide whether the appellant was a tenant. Finally it remanded the matter to the Collector for decision on the question whether the appellant was a tenant or a protected tenant on the merits.

facts.text: Respondent filed petition under Art. 227 Constitution before Bombay High Court against Revenue Tribunal order.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent had companytended before the Revenue Tribunal that the appellant companyld number have the status of a tenant or protected tenant in view of the provisions of the 1948-Act and therefore the respondent filed a petition under Art. 227 of the Constitution of India before the Bombay High Court.

facts.text: Bombay High Court accepted respondent's contentions on s.88 and s.88B, set aside Revenue Tribunal order, restored Collector's dismissal of appellant's application.

anchor.surface_text: Its companytention before the High Court was that in view of s. 88 of the 1948-Act the appellant companyld number claim to be a protected tenant within the meaning of s. 31 of that Act and therefore the order of the Collector was right. It was also companytended that s. 88-B would number apply to the case of the appellant as it came into force on April 1, 1956 after the determination of the tenancy of the appellant by numberice. Both these companytention were accepted by the High Court and the order of the Revenue Tribunal was set aside and in its place the order of the Collector dismissing the appellants application was restored.

facts.text: Bombay High Court certified case fit for appeal to Supreme Court under Art. 133(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon there was an application to the High Court under Art. 133  1   c  of the Constitution and 622. the High Court certified the case as a fit one for appeal to this Court and that is how the matter has companye up before us.

facts.text: Appeal first heard by Division Bench of Supreme Court, referred to larger Bench due to interpretation issues in ss.31,88,89 of 1948 Act and prior SC decisions.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal was first heard by a Division Bench of this Court and has been referred to a larger Bench in view of certain difficulties relating to the interpretation and inter-relation of ss. 31, 88 and 89 of the 1948-Act and in view of two decisions of this Court in Sakharam v. Manikchand 1  and Mohanlal Chunilal Kothari v. Tribhovan Haribhai Tamboli  2 .
therefore the respondent filed a petition under Art. 227 of the Constitution of India before the Bombay High Court.
Thereupon there was an application to the High Court under Art. 133  1   c  of the Constitution and 622.

issues.text: Whether Section 88 prevails over Section 31 such that the appellant would not be entitled to the benefit of Section 31 and could not claim to be a protected tenant under the 1948-Act

anchor.surface_text: Therefore if s. 88 prevailed over s. 31, the appellant would not be entitled to the benefit of s. 31 and could not claim to be a protected tenant under this section.

issues.text: Whether the savings provision in Section 89(2)(b) affects the right, title or interest acquired as a protected tenant under the 1939-Act

anchor.surface_text: the argument is that the interest acquired as a protected tenant under the 1939-Act would thus not be affected in view of this provision in the 1948-Act and it is this argument which we have to examine.

issues.text: Whether there is anything express in the 1948-Act which takes away the interest of a protected tenant acquired before its commencement

anchor.surface_text: The narrow question then is whether there is anything express in the 1948-Act which takes away the interest of a protected tenant acquired before its commencement.

issues.text: Whether Section 88 is an express provision within the meaning of Section 89(2)(b) such that it prevails over any pre-acquired protected tenant interest

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the respondent is that S. 88 is an express provision and in the face of this express provision the interest acquired as a protected tenant under the 1939- Act cannot prevail.

issues.text: Whether Section 88-B applies to the case as it came into force after the determination of the tenancy

anchor.surface_text: It was also contended that s. 88-B would not apply to the case of the appellant as it came into force on April 1, 1956 after the determination of the tenancy of the appellant by notice.

issues.text: What is the inter-relation of Sections 31, 88 and 89 of the 1948-Act

anchor.surface_text: in view of certain difficulties relating to the interpretation and inter-relation of ss. 31, 88 and 89 of the 1948-Act

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the respondent is that S. 88 is an express provision and in the face of this express provision the interest acquired as a protected tenant under the 1939- Act cannot prevail.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e words save as expressly provided in this Act. Therefore, if there is an express provision in the 1948-Act, that will prevail over any right, title o

arguments.court_reasoning: Effect of s.88 renders s.31 non-existent for such leases

arguments.claim: Legislature took away protected status for local authority lessees in public interest via s.88

anchor.surface_text: It may very well be that the legislature thought that the status of a protected tenant should not be given to lessees of lands from a local authority, in the interest of the general, public and therefore took away that interest

arguments.claim: Clauses (a),(b),(c) of s.88(1) apply retrospectively like (d), correcting Mohanlal observation

anchor.surface_text: We may also mention that by an oversight it was stated in Mohanlal Chunilal Kotharis case 1 that clauses a , b and c of S. 88 1 apply to things as they were at the date of the enactment.

holdings.text: Sections 3, 3-A and 4 of the 1939-Act were continued as modified in Schedule I of the 1948-Act only for the purpose of Section 31; no new protected tenants could come into existence under the 1948-Act after December 28, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Further it seems to us obvious that ss. 3, 3-A and 4 of the 1939-Act were not repealed and were continued as modified in Sch. 1 of the 1948-Act for the purpose of s. 31 of the 1948-Act. That section provided as follows- For the purposes of this Act, a person shall be recognised to be a protected tenant if such person has been deemed to be a protected tenant under section 3, 3-A or 4 of the Bombay Tenancy Act, 1939.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of repeal and continuation provisions; purposive reading limits scope to s.31 recognition.

holdings.text: Section 88(1) provides that nothing in the foregoing provisions of the 1948-Act, including Section 31, applies to lands held on lease from a local authority.

anchor.surface_text: Section 88 lays down that nothing in the foregoing provisions of the 1948-Act shall apply inter-alia to lands held on lease from a local authority, like a municipality. As s. 31 is one of the foregoing sections it will not apply

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual application: s.31 is a foregoing provision expressly excluded by s.88(1)(a).

holdings.text: Section 88 takes away the protected tenant status conferred by the 1939-Act for lessees from local authorities under the 1948-Act.

anchor.surface_text: In effect therefore the legislature which had conferred by the 1939-Act the status of a protected tenant on certain persons was taking away that status by enacting s. 88 in the 1948-Act so far as inter alia lessees from a local authority were concerned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical consequence of s.88 rendering s.31 inapplicable; no recognition mechanism left.

holdings.text: The savings clause in Section 89(2)(b) is qualified by 'save as expressly provided in this Act'; an express provision prevails over pre-commencement rights.

anchor.surface_text: But the clause nothing in this Act shall affect or be deemed to affect is qualified by the words save as expressly provided in this Act. Therefore, if there is an express provision in the 1948-Act, that will prevail over any right, title or interest etc. acquired before its commencement.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of qualifying phrase in savings clause.

holdings.text: Section 88(1)(a) is an express provision within Section 89(2)(b) that takes away pre-acquired protected tenant interest for local authority leases.

anchor.surface_text: In view of this express provision contained in s. 88 1 a , the appellant cannot claim the benefit of s. 31 nor can it be said that his interest as protected tenant is saved by s. 89 2 b . This in our opinion is the plain effect of the provisions contained in s. 31, s. 88 and s. 89 2 b of the 1948-Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.88 renders s.31 non-existent for such lands, effectively divesting status despite savings; applies to facts.

holdings.text: Sakharam v. Manikchand incorrectly read more into Section 89(2)(b) than justified and failed to give full effect to 'save as expressly provided'.

anchor.surface_text: With respect, it seems to us that more has been read in that case in s. 89 2 b than is justified under the terms of that provision. It was also observed in that case that the provisions of s. 88 were entirely prospective and were not intended in any sense to be of confiscatory character

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes prior SC decision; textual re-analysis.

holdings.text: Clauses (a), (b), and (c) of Section 88(1) apply both retrospectively and prospectively, not limited to the date of enactment; corrects observation in Mohanlal Chunilal Kothari.

anchor.surface_text: We may also mention that by an oversight it was stated in Mohanlal Chunilal Kotharis case 1 that clauses a , b and c of S. 88 1 apply to things as they were at the date of the enactment. It is however clear that clauses a , b and c of S. 88 1 also apply in the future.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of 'held on lease'; analogy to clause (d); follows Mohanlal ratio with correction.

holdings.text: The Bombay High Court correctly held that Section 88(1)(a) is an express provision taking away protected tenant interest under the 1939-Act.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter, the view taken by the High Court in the judgment under appeal that s. 88 1 a is an express provision which takes away the interest of protected tenants under the 1939-Act must be held to be correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms lower court on inter-relation of ss.31,88,89.

anchor.surface_text: Sakharam v. Manikchand 1  and Mohanlal Chunilal Kothari v. Tribhovan Haribhai Tamboli  2 . It has been contended on behalf of the appellant that Sakharams case 1 fully covers the present case and on the basis of that case the appeal should be allowed.

precedents.cited_proposition: interpretation and inter-relation of ss. 31, 88 and 89 of the 1948-Act

precedents.citation: Mohanlal Chunilal Kothari v. Tribhovan Haribhai Tamboli  2

anchor.surface_text: Mohanlal Chunilal Kothari v. Tribhovan Haribhai Tamboli  2 . It has been contended on behalf of the appellant that Sakharams case 1 fully covers the present case and on the basis of that case the appeal should be allowed. On the other hand, learned counsel for the respondent contends that on the ratio of Mohanlal Chunilal Kotharis case,  2   the appellant should be held to be number a protected tenant

precedents.case_name: Mohanlal Chunilal Kothari v. Tribhovan Haribhai Tamboli
precedents.cited_proposition: interpretation and inter-relation of ss. 31, 88 and 89 of the 1948-Act; ratio applies to s.88(1)(d) and by extension to s.88(1)(a)(b)(c)

anchor.surface_text: Sakharams case 1 fully covers the present case and on the basis of that case the appeal should be allowed. On the other hand, learned counsel for the respondent contends that on the ratio of Mohanlal Chunilal Kotharis case,  2   the appellant should be held to be number a protected tenant and that considerations which applied to the interpretation of s. 88  1    d  equally applied to the interpretation of s. 88  1   a ,  b  and  c .

precedents.cited_proposition: fully covers the present case (s.89(2)(b) saves protected tenant status from s.88 for leases from local authority)

anchor.surface_text: on the ratio of Mohanlal Chunilal Kotharis case,  2   the appellant should be held to be number a protected tenant and that considerations which applied to the interpretation of s. 88  1    d  equally applied to the interpretation of s. 88  1   a ,  b  and  c . It is further urged on behalf of the respondent that in view of the latter decision, the decision in Sakharams case 1  numberlonger holds the field.

precedents.cited_proposition: ratio that appellant is not protected tenant; considerations for s.88(1)(d) apply to s.88(1)(a)(b)(c); Sakharam no longer holds field

anchor.surface_text: It now remains to refer to Sakharams case 1 which certainly supports the contention raised on behalf of the appellant. With respect, it seems to us that more has been read in that case in s. 89  2   b  than is justified under the terms of that provision. It was  1  1962 2 S.C.R. 59. also observed in that case that the provisions of s. 88 were entirely prospective and were number intended in any sense to be of companyfiscatory character, and that s. 89 2   b  showed clearly an intention to companyserve such rights as were acquired before the companymencement of 1948-Act.

precedents.cited_proposition: s.88 provisions are prospective and non-confiscatory; s.89(2)(b) conserves pre-1948 rights as protected tenants despite s.88
precedents.cited_holding: provisions of s. 88 were entirely prospective and were not intended in any sense to be of confiscatory character, and that s. 89(2)(b) showed clearly an intention to conserve such rights as were acquired before the commencement of 1948-Act

anchor.surface_text: We are supported in the view we have taken by the decision of this Court in Mohanlal Chunilal Kotharis case 1  where it was held that S. 88  1  d  would be rendered companypletely ineffective if it was number to be applied retrospectively, though it was added in that case that it did number affect the rights acquired under the earlier Act of 1939. anchor.surface_text: Further if a numberification under S. 88  1   d  companyld be retrospective upto the date of the 1948-Act we can see numberreason on the language of this section to hold that it was retrospective only upto 1948 and would number affect the rights acquired tinder the 1939-Act. We may also mention that by an oversight it was stated in Mohanlal Chunilal Kotharis case 1  that clauses  a ,  b  and  c  of S. 88 1  apply to things as they were at the date of the enactment.

precedents.cited_proposition: clauses (a), (b), (c) of s.88(1) apply prospectively only to date of enactment; distinction from cl.(d)
